column1: Rule 1: Modifiers containing both a carboxylic acid group (–COOH) and an amino group (–NH2) with an alkyl chain of 5 or fewer carbons tend to result in a high yield.
column2: Rule 2: Modifiers with a phenyl group (–C6H5) and a hydroxyl group (–OH) at the para position tend to result in a high yield.
column3: Rule 3: Modifiers containing a sulfanyl group (–SH) and a hydroxyl group (–OH) tend to result in a high yield.
column4: Rule 4: Modifiers with a pyridine ring and a carboxylic acid group (–COOH) tend to result in a low yield unless paired with electron-withdrawing groups like nitro (–NO2) or cyano (–CN).
column5: Rule 5: Modifiers with multiple electron-donating groups such as methoxy (–OCH3) or amino (–NH2) tend to result in a low yield.
column6: Rule 6: Modifiers containing a nitro group (–NO2) at the para position tend to result in a high yield.
column7: Rule 7: Modifiers with a trifluoromethyl group (–CF3) tend to result in a low yield unless combined with groups that can donate electrons.
column8: Rule 8: Modifiers with an indole group tend to result in a high yield.
column9: Rule 9: Modifiers with a benzofuran group tend to result in a high yield.
column10: Rule 10: Modifiers with an alkyl chain of 7 or more carbons tend to result in a low yield.
column11: Rule 11: Modifiers with a carboxylic acid group (–COOH) and a bromine atom (–Br) tend to result in a high yield.
column12: Rule 12: Modifiers with a formyl group (–CHO) tend to result in a low yield.
column13: Rule 13: Modifiers with a pyridine ring tend to result in a low yield unless paired with electron-withdrawing groups.
column14: Rule 14: Modifiers with a hydroxyl group (–OH) and a sulfanyl group (–SH) tend to result in a high yield.
column15: Rule 15: Modifiers with a combination of electron-withdrawing groups such as nitro (–NO2) and trifluoromethyl (–CF3) tend to result in a high yield.
